1

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
equity investment in Aureos South Asia Fund, L.L.C. (the Fund) of up to $17.5 million or 25% of 
the Fund’s total share capital, whichever is less. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: BACKGROUND, CHALLENGES, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELETED] 
 
The story of small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in South Asia is one of great 
2. 
opportunity and great constraint. Although economic conditions differ widely in India, Sri Lanka, 
and Bangladesh1, the SME sector shows great promise within the region. In India, this promise 
derives from significant economic expansion and an SME sector poised to take off in response 
to increased demand. In Sri Lanka, it takes the form of new opportunities and new optimism for 
the  SME  sector  following  the  end  of  decades  of  violence  and  unrest.  In  Bangladesh,  where 
SMEs have been constrained by a volatile political and economic landscape, opportunities exist 
for opportunistic firms to make true gains in productivity and efficiency if given the financial and 
human  resources  they  need.  In  all  three  economies,  the  promise  of  the  SME  sector  is 
constrained by the lack of availability of appropriate financing modalities to fund expansion and 
improvement. This lack of financing, and in particular the dearth of private equity funding, serves 
as the Fund’s context for a business case that delivers both financial returns and development 
impact.  
 
A. 

India 

 
3. 
The  Economy:  Positive  Dynamics,  Healthy  Growth,  and  Opening  Markets.  The 
Indian economy is the world’s fourth largest economy, when measured in terms of purchasing 
power  parity,  after  the  United  States,  People’s Republic  of China,  and  Japan,  with  strong  and 
growing demand from an expanding middle class. Over the past 10 years, the Government of 
India  has  introduced  wide-ranging  changes  aimed  at  accelerating  economic  growth  and 
integrating the Indian economy with the rest of the world. These reforms have primarily been in 
the direction of (i) reducing the role of government in industry and trade, and (ii) improving the 
competitiveness of Indian industry. In response to liberalization, deregulation, privatization, and 
relaxation of restrictions on foreign investment and the capital account, gross domestic product 
(GDP) growth accelerated and remained strong until the mid-1990s. Despite a minor economic 
downturn  between  1997  and  2000,  sustained  growth  between  2000  and  2004  revealed  that 
Indian  companies  are  adjusting  to  (i) operating  in  a  liberalized  domestic  economy;  (ii)  refining 
their strategies for export development and penetration of foreign markets; and (iii) adapting to 
fluctuations in the business cycle, vicissitudes in demand, and exogenous shocks.  
 
The  SME  Sector:  Poised  for  Growth,  Ready  to  Capitalize  on  New  Opportunities. 
4. 
SMEs  have  been  quick  to  recognize  the  opportunities  generated  by  the  process  of  economic 
liberalization.  As  the  absence  of  linkages  between  SMEs  and  larger  companies  is  redressed 
and the latter reach downward into the supply chain to meet growing demand, the SME sector 
has become poised for rapid growth. Forward-looking SMEs have realized the need to (i) build 
                                                 
1  Listed  in  this  order  throughout  the  RRP  to  reflect,  largest  to  smallest,  anticipated  aggregate  investments  by  the 

Fund. 

 

  2 

skill  bases,  (ii)  achieve  cost  competitiveness,  and  (iii)  gain  market  access  rapidly  to  meet  this 
demand.  To  secure  participation  in  the  supply  chains  of  larger  domestic  and  international 
players, the more dynamic SMEs have begun to (i) strengthen their design and innovation skills, 
(ii) pursue niche production and services models, and (iii) attract world-class personnel. Years 
of  underinvestment  and  SMEs’  realization  of  the  urgent  need  to  scale  up  in  order  to  compete 
therefore suggests a period not just of rapid expansion, but also of considerable consolidation. 
For  those  SMEs  that  focus  on  quality,  delivery,  and  reliability,  opportunities  abound  for  strong 
growth in domestic and international markets. When they are granted access to both financing 
and strategic acumen, SMEs are poised to flourish in both domestic and export markets.   
 
5. 
SME  Financing:  Highly  Constrained  in  Both  Size  and  Scope  of  Products.  For 
decades,  India’s  financial  institutions  have  suffered  from  the  same  protectionism  and 
overregulation  that  constrained  growth  and  efficiency  in  the  rest  of  the  economy.  Today,  the 
financing  culture  in  the  country  is  rooted  in  asset-backed  lending  and  risk  aversion.  After 
decades of financing the working capital requirements of predominantly large, often state-owned 
enterprises, most banks remain uncomfortable with introducing higher risk products; cash-flow-
based lending and risk capital remain unfamiliar territory for Indian banks. The risk aversion of 
financial institutions has severely limited financing options for SMEs in India. Lending to SMEs 
falls  largely  into  the  domain  of  the  so-called  unorganized  sector,  populated  by  informal  and 
semiformal  purveyors  of  short-term  capital  at  punitive  interest  rates.  The  cash-flow-based 
lending  that  banks  do  provide  is  exclusively  short  term,  and  used  solely  for  working  capital 
requirements. Although banks provide asset-backed lending, high-growth SMEs often either do 
not have sufficient assets for this type of financing, or bump up again India’s conservative bank 
lending policies (which typically do not exceed a debt-to-equity ratio of 1:1).  
 
6. 
Private Equity Industry: Much Needed, but Nascent. Given these constraints, private 
equity becomes not only an attractive option for many companies, but also in many cases the 
only  viable  option.  The  private  equity  industry  in  India  plays  a  critical  role  in  the  economic 
growth process by diversifying the sources of finance available for entrepreneurial companies. 
Specifically, private equity not only provides SMEs with long-term funding, but also allows them 
the ability to buy fixed assets and use them as collateral for commercial bank loans to leverage 
their  expansion.  Private  equity  finance  thus  has  the  potential  to  produce  greater  numbers  of 
attractive  clients  for  loans,  letters  of  credit,  and  other  banking  services.  The  assessment  of 
India’s private sector by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) recommends providing assistance 
to  increase  the  variety  of  financing  instruments  that  private  firms  can  access.2  The  venture 
capital and private equity industry in India is over 15 years old, and is growing at a healthy pace. 
Currently more than 35 private equity and venture capital firms are investing in the country with 
over $4 billion invested as of December 2003. However, the market remains relatively small and 
underdeveloped;  the  rate  of  private  equity  investment  as  a  percentage  of  GDP  in  2003  was 
0.14%, in contrast to 1.0% in the United States and 0.58% in the United Kingdom.3  While many 
investors  have  increased  their  allocation  to  private  equity  as  an  alternative  asset  class, 

                                                 
2  ADB. 2004. Private Sector Assessment: India. Manila (p. 48). 
3  Private equity investment rate in percent of GDP in 2003: 1.0% in the United States, 0.59% in Singapore, 0.58% in 
United Kingdom, 0.47% in the Republic of Korea, 0.14% in India, 0.12% in the People’s Republic of China, 0.08% 
in the Philippines, 0.03% in Thailand, and 0.03% in Viet Nam. Venture Capital Journal. The 2004 Guide to Venture 
Capital in Asia. Hong Kong, China; World Bank. 2004. World Development Indicators. Washington DC; and ADB. 
2005.  Private  Sector  Operations  Department  Investment  Funds  Operations.  Informal  Board  Briefing.  Manila  (17 
March). (Although precisely  comparable data is not  yet available for 2004 and 2005,  unofficial data  from the UTI 
Venture  Funds  website  and  other  sources  indicate  that  the  private  equity  investment  rate  in  percent  of  GDP  in 
2004  was  about  0.19%  in  India,  and  is  tracking  at  a  similar  level  thus  far  for  2005.  However,  despite  these 
increases the private equity penetration rate in India still lags far behind levels in more developed economies.)   

 3

underinvestment  in  private  equity  continues  because  of  a shortage  of fund  managers  with  the 
experience and financial backing necessary to ensure the sustainability of their operations.  
 
 
B. 

Sri Lanka 

8. 
The Economy: Optimism and New Beginnings Following 20 Years of Violence. The 
outbreak of civil war in 1983 led to 20 years of economic underperformance in Sri Lanka. The 
combination  of  political  instability,  violence,  and  terrorism  (i)  hampered  sustained  economic 
growth and development, (ii) disrupted the flow of goods and services, (iii) skewed fiscal policy 
toward  war-related  expenditure,  (iv)  discouraged  foreign  investment,  and  (v) generated  an 
entrenched  short-term  perspective 
throughout  a  business  culture  shaped  by  conflict. 
Unsurprisingly, the signing of the ceasefire in 2002 between the Government and Tamil Tigers 
saw a resurgence in economic growth, with real GDP growing between 4% and 5.9% for the last 
4 years. Confidence in the peace process remains fragile, and squabbling over the distribution 
of emergency relief following the tsunami of December 2004 has augmented tensions between 
the  Government  and  the  rebels.  Nevertheless,  much  of  the  private  sector  and  the  general 
population  remain  cautiously  optimistic  that  a  return  to  hostilities  has  become  increasingly 
unlikely.  This  has  led  to  a  reorientation  of  businesses  to  focus  on  (i)  long-term  growth,  (ii)  an 
increase  in  foreign  direct  investment,  (iii)  increasing  private  sector  investment,  and  (iv) 
increased development assistance.  
 
9. 
The  SME  Sector:  Poised  for  Growth,  Ready  to  Capitalize  on  New  Opportunities. 
With the diminishing of violence and the increasing stability of the operating environment in Sri 
Lanka, the SME sector is in a highly favorable position to capitalize on new opportunities in an 
optimistic  environment.  Businesses  are  beginning  to  focus  on  longer  term  growth  and 
investment strategies. Additionally, the country is witnessing the establishment of manufacturing 
facilities  by  foreign  companies  that  view  Sri  Lanka  as  a  cheaper  and  more  effective  route  for 
penetration  of  the  Indian  market;  and  foreign  companies  are  eager  to  take  advantage  of  the 
preferential  tariff  regime  under  the  Indo-Lanka  Free  Trade  Agreement.  Lastly,  the  sharp 
increase in development assistance following the tsunami of December 2004 has begun to feed 
through  to  the  construction  and  services  sectors,  offering  up  opportunities  to  well  positioned 
SMEs in those industries as well.  
 
10. 
SME Financing: Available, but Insufficient to Meet Financial and Strategic Needs. 
Compared with their Indian counterparts, Sri Lankan banks have actually displayed an unusual 
appetite  for  lending,  including  relatively  high-risk  short-term  lending.  However,  banks  are  very 
reluctant to provide long-term financing, and equity is almost completely unavailable. Alternative 
sources of capital somewhat analogous to private equity in Sri Lanka include (i) family financing, 
(ii) funds secured from high net worth individuals, (iii) investments made from balance sheets of 
large corporations into smaller companies in related industries, and (iv) finances raised by some 
medium-sized  companies  from  the  capital  markets.  By  and  large,  banks’  eagerness  to  lend, 
coupled  with  firms’  general  reluctance  to  allow  external  participation  in  management  has 
propagated a preference for debt financing. Despite the availability of short-term loans, the lack 
of availability of private equity and long-term expansion financing mean that the particular needs 
of SMEs are in large measure not met.  
 
11. 
Private  Equity  Industry:  Much  Needed,  but  Nascent. Volatile  political  and  economic 
conditions, high interest rates, and a tendency to seek financing to meet interim working capital 
requirements  rather  than  to  realize  long-term  investment  strategies  have  often  skewed  SMEs’ 
structural  underpinnings  and  growth  strategies.  For  these  reasons,  many  Sri  Lankan  SMEs 

 

 

  4 

require  both  long-term  risk  capital  and  managerial  and  strategic  reorientation  to  effectively 
exploit  market  opportunities  within  and  beyond  Sri  Lanka,  and  thereby  achieve  sustained 
growth.  This  makes  it  a  promising  market  for  private  equity  to  flourish.  However,  according  to 
the  Asian  Venture  Capital  Journal  database  (footnote  4),  the  only  private  equity  fund 
management company  currently located in Sri  Lanka is the local office of Aureos. Indeed, the 
penetration rate of private equity as a percentage of GDP in Sri Lanka is less than 0.1%.  
 
 
C. 

Bangladesh 

13. 
The Economy: Improving but Still Highly Challenging for the Private Sector. One of 
the world’s poorest countries, Bangladesh suffers from (i) a debilitating combination of political 
instability,  (ii)  poor  governance  and  endemic  corruption,  (iii)  limited  natural  resources,  (iv) 
adverse  weather  conditions,  and  (v)  a  limited  manufacturing  base.  However,  improvements  in 
macroeconomic  management  and  monetary  and  fiscal  policymaking  have  enabled  the 
Government, multilateral institutions, and funding agencies to widen their focus from improving 
economic  fundamentals  to  addressing  some  of  the  systemic  and  structural  weaknesses 
impeding  private  sector  development.  Renewed  emphasis  is  being  placed  on  (i) increasing 
competitiveness and enhancing management capacity in the banking sector, (ii) reforming loss-
making state-owned enterprises, (iii) combating corruption through the recently established Anti-
Corruption  Commission,  and  (iv)  improving  tax  administration  and  expenditure  prioritization.  If 
and when the private sector will detect concrete improvements in the operating environment is 
an open question. However, there is cautious optimism that the policy framework is moving in 
the right direction. 
 
14. 
In the 1970s, the Government moved away from its socialist orientation and committed 
to  reduce its  involvement  in industry  and  increase  the  role  of  the  private  sector.  However,  the 
public  sector  still  includes  over  40%  of  Bangladesh’s  manufacturing  and  utility  assets. 
Privatization efforts are hindered by a lack of political commitment, bureaucratic resistance, and 
labor union opposition.  
 
15. 
The  SME  Sector:  A  Challenging  Environment.  Not  surprisingly,  the  volatile  political 
and economic landscape has hampered growth and improvements in productivity and efficiency 
of Bangladeshi companies. The commercial landscape for SMEs is challenging, as they usually 
lack  the  resources  and  political  clout  required  to  navigate  the  labyrinthine  bureaucracy 
regulating license approvals, export permits, or other certifications. Competition among SMEs is 
often  vigorous  in  the  domestic  context,  but  few  have  managed  to  pursue  regional  expansion 
strategies  because  of  the  complexities  involved  and  their  disadvantageous  position  vis-à-vis 
larger  corporations.    Indeed,  throughout  the  1990s,  larger  enterprises  grew  faster  than  SMEs, 
which  generally  use  little  capital  to  produce  simple  goods  for  the  domestic  market.  The 
challenging  operating  environment  in  Bangladesh  requires  SMEs  to  be  creative  in  order  to 
survive and grow. As a result, managerial practices tend to be unorthodox, governance is often 
weak,  and  strategic  planning  is  either  nonexistent  or  ad  hoc.  Corruption,  irregular  accounting 
practices, and tight control of family-owned companies only add to the challenges for SMEs.  
 
16. 
SME  Financing:  Largely  Unavailable.  SMEs  face  huge  constraints.  The  Bangladeshi 
financial  services  sector  is  small  and  undeveloped.  Commercial  banks  are  hampered  with 
problems,  including  nonperforming  loans,  low  loan  recovery,  failure  to  meet  capital  adequacy 
requirements,  insider  trading,  and  fraudulent  transactions.  State-owned  enterprises  are  the 
traditional clients of the banks; they receive favorable bank terms, crowding out the resources 
available  for  the  private  sector.  This  is  one  of  the  major  reasons  for  the  slow  growth  of  the 

 5

private sector, and of SMEs in particular. SMEs are therefore generally unable to obtain even 
the most basic type of bank loan, much less any other type of formal financing.   
 
17. 
Private  Equity  Industry:  Much  Needed,  but  Nascent.  In  addition  to  financing  for 
growth and assistance in the elaboration of clear, well-planned growth strategies, Bangladeshi 
SMEs urgently require professionalization and modernization. In this context, provision of equity 
to SMEs would be beneficial to individual companies, and would indeed benefit the economy as 
a whole. The necessity of injecting fresh capital, in the form of private equity, into the economy 
is  even  more  critical  following  the  tsunami  in  December  2004,  which  redirected  financial 
resources  toward  disaster  relief,  and  away  from  small  private  companies.  At  this  point  the 
private equity industry in Bangladesh is virtually nonexistent.   
 
 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED FUND 

Fund Management   

Objectives and Description  

 
A. 
 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELETED] 
 
27. 
The primary objective of the Fund will be to make equity or equity-related investments in 
SMEs  in  South  Asia  that  demonstrate  strong  potential  for  profitable  growth  and  regional 
expansion.  The  Fund  will  invest  in  entrepreneurial  companies  in  high-potential  industries 
capitalizing  on  strong  demand  from  both  domestic  and  export  markets.  Additionally,  the  Fund 
will seek to promote regional integration of the private sector by supporting expansion of local 
SMEs into regional corporations that benefit from and contribute to economic integration among 
countries of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC).   
 
C. 
 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELETED] 
 
 
31. 
Fund  Manager.  The  Fund  will  be  managed  by  Aureos  South  Asia  Managers  Ltd.  (the 
Fund  Manager),  a  company  established  under  the  laws  of  Mauritius.  The  Fund  Manager  is  a 
wholly  owned  subsidiary  of  Aureos  Capital  Ltd.  (Aureos),  a  global  manager  of  SME  private 
equity  funds  (and  also  a  Mauritius  company).  The  Aureos  board  in  Mauritius  is  advised  by  a 
central  team  based  in  London,  Aureos  Advisers  Limited  (AAL),  a  wholly  owned  subsidiary  of 
Aureos. Aureos was born out of what used to be CDC Funds Group, pioneers of private equity 
in many of the emerging markets in the SME sector.  The CDC Funds Groups was established 
in  1990;  all  of  its  funds  have  been  exclusively  invested  in  developing  countries.  When  CDC 
spun  out  its  private  equity  funds  business  in  July  2001,  Aureos  was  established  as  a  fund 
manager. More than 10 management companies originally owned and managed by CDC, which 
in  turn  managed  14  SME  venture  capital  country-specific  funds,  were  consolidated  under  the 
Aureos umbrella.  
 
33. 
Headquarters.  Aureos  is  headquartered  in  London,  and  focuses  solely  on  operating 
SME funds around the world, thereby combining local presence with a global network. Aureos 
leverages its headquarters for the purposes of centralized reporting, compliance and procedural 
control, knowledge management, training and dissemination of best practices, exit assistance, 
cash control supervision, and cross-fertilization between regional teams. The London team has 

 

 

  6 

established  operating  systems  and  standards  across  all  Aureos  funds,  providing  general 
compliance  assurance  to  investors  on  the  nature,  method,  and  manner  of  investment  activity. 
Other central management team responsibilities include the provision of staff training and career 
development strategies. 
 
35. 
Local  Office.  The  local  teams  in  Bangalore,  Colombo,  and  Mumbai  carry  the  main 
responsibility  for  identifying  potential  investee  companies,  carrying  out  transactions,  and 
monitoring and managing portfolio companies.  
 
 
E. 
 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION HAS BEEN DELETED] 
 

Governance Structure  

1. 

Fund Manager 

The  Fund  Manager  will  (i)  identify  potential  investment  opportunities;  (ii) screen 
47. 
investment proposals by making a thorough appraisal of the feasibility and risks; (iii) supervise 
and  monitor  investments;  (iv)  dispose  of  the  shares  of companies  invested  at the  time  of  exit; 
and  (v)  undertake  all  accounting,  compliance,  and  investor  reporting  for  the  Fund.  The  Fund 
Manager  will  be  contractually  bound  to  carry  out  its  responsibilities  according  to  the  Fund’s 
investment  policy.  To  encourage  individual  team  members  to  select  companies  with  the  most 
promise  for  entrepreneurial  growth,  and  to  enhance  the  value  of  their  investees,  the  team 
members earn a carried interest, i.e., performance fee, if the return to investors exceeds 6% per 
year, after the value of their invested capital has been returned.  
 
 

IV. 

INVESTMENT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

 
A.  Justification 

1. 

Development Impact 

59. 
development objectives: 
 

By  providing  financing  for  this  transaction,  ADB  intends  to  achieve  the  following 

Mobilize long-term capital in the form of private equity for SMEs in South Asia to 
finance expansion and productivity improvements. 

Diversify  the  sources  of  finance  available  to  SMEs  by  including  equity  finance, 
which  enables  SMEs  to  buy  fixed  assets  and  to  use  them  as  collateral  for 
commercial bank loans to leverage their expansion. This dynamic process helps 
South Asian SMEs to evolve into larger enterprises.  

Demonstrate  to  the  private  sector  that  investments  in  entrepreneurial  SMEs  in 
South Asia can be commercially attractive, thus catalyzing further investments by 
building  up 
investments.  This 
demonstration  effect  will  be  achieved  most  effectively  by  supporting  domestic 
private equity teams. 

to  manage  private  equity 

local  capacity 

(i) 

 
(ii) 

 
(iii) 

 

 7

Provide management advice to SMEs  in financial planning, business expansion 
strategies,  human  resource  development,  and  implementation  of  international 
standards of corporate governance.  

Create sustainable employment in the SME sector in South Asia. 

Stimulate private sector development to serve as a vehicle for the country’s long-
term economic growth and stability. 

 
(vii)  Contribute  to  the  development  of  a  well-functioning  regulatory  and  legal 
environment  in  South  Asia  through  the  reporting  by  the  Fund  Manager  on 
regulatory issues that their SME portfolio companies encounter. This information 
will be reported on a regular basis to the South Asia Department to support the 
formulation of a supportive regulatory framework for expanding SMEs.  

 
(viii)  Support the development and growth of South Asia’s private equity and portfolio 

management professionals by supporting a first-time fund management team. 

Promote regional integration of the private sector by supporting the expansion of 
local  SMEs  into  regional  corporations  that  benefit  from  and  contribute  to 
economic integration among member countries of SAARC. 

2. 

Value Added by ADB 

The involvement of ADB will provide the following valued added: 

Catalytic and demonstration effect. Given the significant risks and challenges 
facing  potential  investors,  ADB  will  serve  a  catalytic  role  in  attracting  additional 
local  and  foreign  long-term  private  investments  to  India,  Sri  Lanka,  and 
Bangladesh.  ADB  will  demonstrate  by  its  intervention  the  credibility  of  SME 
equity finance in the three countries and mobilize capital to support other private 
equity funds. 

Private  sector  development.  The  Fund,  similar  to  others  in  which  PSOD 
invests, will make a direct contribution to private sector development. The Fund 
will  employ  market-based  mechanisms  to  develop  profitable  and  sustainable 
enterprises.  ADB’s  contribution  to  this  type  of  initiative  helps  its  DMCs  to 
implement 
respective  country-specific  private  sector  development 
strategies.  

their 

Value added by the Fund Manager. ADB will support domestic teams providing 
hands-on management advice to SMEs in financial planning, business expansion 
strategies,  human  resource  development,  and  implementation  of  international 
standards of corporate governance.  

B.  Measuring Development Effectiveness 

61. 
PSOD  and  the  Operations  Evaluation  Department  are  formulating  guidelines  for 
implementing  the  Good  Practice  Standards  for  Evaluation  of  Private  Sector  Investment 

(iv) 

 
(v) 
 
(vi) 

 
(ix) 

(i) 

 
(ii) 

(iii) 

 

 

 

 

60. 
 

 

  8 

 

(i) 

(ii) 

 
(iii) 

Operations,  which  were  prepared  by  the  Evaluation  Cooperation  Group4  of  the  multilateral 
development banks.5 These standards cover (i) roles of the independent evaluation department 
and the private sector department itself, (ii) evaluation dimensions for private sector operations, 
(iii) nature of annual reporting, and (iv) dissemination of reports and lessons. According to the 
standards,  the  three  principal  dimensions  for  private  sector  evaluation  are  development 
outcome,  investment  profitability  for  the  institution,  and  operational  effectiveness.  PSOD  will 
measure the expected development outcome of the Fund at the Fund and subproject levels, as 
well as beyond the Fund by monitoring certain performance measures throughout the life of the 
Fund. The performance measures are grouped into three key areas:  

Business  performance.  The  extent  to  which  the  Fund  has  reached  its 
objectives in terms of the overall profitability and commercial viability of the Fund 
and subprojects. 

Economic sustainability. The effects of the Fund and subprojects on the DMC’s 
economy,  and  the  associated  benefits  and  costs.  These  measures  assess  the 
extent  to  which  the  Fund  improved  the  allocation  of  resources  and  provision  of 
financial  services  to  viable  private  enterprises,  and  evaluate  whether  the 
subprojects directly generated positive effects on the local economy.  

Private  sector  development.  The  impact  of  the  Fund  on  private  sector 
development  beyond  the  Fund  itself  and  its  immediate  stakeholders,  e.g.,  the 
Fund’s  contribution  to  the  growth  of  viable  financial  institutions  and  financial 
markets development. 

Quantitative and qualitative measures of performance are summarized in Appendix 1.  

 
62. 
 
C.  Environmental and Social Safeguard Policies 

The  Fund 

is  classified  as  category  FI  (financial 

63. 
intermediary);  no  significant 
environmental impact is anticipated. The Fund’s impact on resettlement and indigenous peoples 
has been classified as C (no impact). All companies in which the Fund invests will be required to 
comply  with  national  environmental  laws,  regulations,  and  standards,  as  well  as  ADB’s 
environmental and social safeguard policies. 
 
64. 
The  implementation  of  an  environmental  management  system,  which  includes  ADB’s 
environmental and social safeguards, adds value to the Fund. Close coordination with ADB will 
be  necessary  to  ensure  that  the  Fund  Manager  possesses  the  capacity  to  screen  and 
categorize prospective investments on the basis of environmental and social impact. The Fund 
will ensure that at least two of its employees (or one senior officer and one or more environment 
consultants)  receive  environmental  training  approved  by  the  advisory  committee.  The  Fund 
Manager will appoint a senior officer to implement and supervise the environmental and social 
management  system,  and  an  environment  coordinator  to  conduct  reviews  of  investee 
companies  with  respect  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  and  all  applicable  environmental  and 
social  requirements.  The  Fund  will  develop  an  environmental  management  system  that  is 
satisfactory to ADB in accordance with the guidelines in Appendix 6. 
                                                 
4   The  Evaluation  Cooperation  Group  was  formed  by  the  multilateral  development  banks  to  design  common 
evaluation standards for private sector operations. The group’s work is ongoing and some aspects of the present 
evaluation framework might change to correspond to best practices. 

5  Multilateral  Development  Banks  Evaluation  Cooperation  Group.  2001.  Good  Practice  Standards  for  Evaluation  of 

Private Sector Investment Operations. 

  

9

 
65. 
Aureos  has  extensive  in-house  environmental  management  system  (EMS)  capabilities, 
managed through a business principles unit by one of Aureos’ senior staff. Aureos headquarters 
has  produced  an  extensive  handbook  articulating  the  standards  and  expectations  of  the 
organization with regard to business principles; and environmental, social, and health and safety 
issues.  It  provides  staff  with  a  comprehensive  and  rigorous  road  map  for  evaluating  EMS-
related  issues  at  deal  origination,  screening,  due  diligence,  investment  management,  and  exit 
stages of the transaction. Every new Aureos employee receives training in the EMS standards 
and procedures, and every employee receives yearly training on modifications or new elements 
of the EMS policy at the Aureos annual meeting. Thus, the Fund is well positioned to implement 
whatever environmental and social safeguards are appropriate.   
 
D. 

Anticorruption, and Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism 

The  Fund  was  advised  of  ADB’s  anticorruption  policy6  and  policy  relating  to  the 
70. 
combating of money laundering and the financing of terrorism.7 Consistent with its commitment 
to  good  governance,  accountability,  and  transparency,  ADB  will  require  the  Fund  Manager  to 
institute, maintain, and comply with internal procedures and controls following international best 
practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption or money laundering activities or the 
financing  of  terrorism,  and  covenant  with  ADB  to  refrain  from  engaging  in  such  activities.  The 
investment  documentation  between  ADB  and  the  Fund  will  allow  ADB  to  investigate  any 
violation or potential violation of these undertakings. The Fund Manager already has in place an 
extensive framework for training employees in the prevention of money laundering, and should 
be well positioned to comply with ADB’s requirements. 
 
E. 

Investment Limitations and Waiver 

71.  
The proposed investment is within ADB's country and single project exposure limits for 
private  sector  operations,  but  once  made,  will  exceed  the  industry  exposure  limit  for  capital 
markets  and  investment  funds,  which  is  currently  set  at  15%  of  the  private  sector  portfolio. 
ADB’s current private sector portfolio of capital market and investment funds represents 18.96% 
of  total  exposure  and  following  this  investment  would  increase  to  19.79%.  ADB’s  Risk 
Management  Unit  (RMU)  and  PSOD  have  been  in  discussions  on  reclassifying  the  industry 
sectors  and  revising  the  limits  to  better  reflect ADB’s  strategic  foci.8  While  the  capital  markets 
and investment funds industry comprises mainly private equity funds, most equity funds invest 
in  turn  in  many  different  industries  and  companies,  hence  ADB’s  true  exposure  is  to  the 
underlying industries invested in by each fund, not to the generic industry of capital markets and 
investment  funds.  The  new  industry  sectors  and  limits  will  reflect  this.  As  a  result,  RMU  has 
considered  the  breach  of  the  industry  exposure  limit  and  supports  a  waiver  of  this  limit  by 
Management for this proposed investment. Management has agreed to grant such waiver.9

V. 

ASSURANCES 

72. 
ADB will enter into suitable documentation that will indicate ADB’s commitment to invest 
an  amount  up  to  the  lesser  of  $17,500,000  or  25%  of  the  Fund’s  total  share  capital  following 
approval of the investment by ADB’s Board of Directors. ADB will not be the largest investor in 
the  Fund.  ADB  will  satisfy  itself  with  the  terms  and  conditions  of  all  principal  documents 
associated with its investment in the Fund, including the management agreement between the 
Fund and the Fund Manager. 
 
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  investment  in  Aureos  South  Asia  Fund,  L.L.C.  would 
73. 
comply  with  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the 
investment of up to the lesser of $17,500,000 or 25% of the Fund’s total share capital in Aureos 
South Asia Fund, L.L.C. from ADB’s ordinary capital resources.
